_diffuse_xtm.Description: Standard for any diffuse type image

_specular_xtm.Description: Standard for reflections, need a Black And White map (Non-Color Node)

_roughness_xtm.Description: Standard for Roughness Map, need a Black And White map

_metal_xtm.Description: Standard for Metal Map, need a Black and White map

_normal_xtm.Description: Normal maps must be in OpenGl format, so if they are made for Direct-X engines, it would be better to invert the Y's (the Green channel) to work correctly in Blender

_occlusion_xtm.Description: This is to simulate a fake environmental occlusion.

_displace_xtm.Description: This map can do double function, both as a Bump and as a Displace. It will be automatically recognized as such by Extreme PBR

_bump_xtm.Description: This map can only be a bump, it will not be recognized as a Displacement, but can be added in combination with the Displace node.

_emission_xtm.Description: This map can be in color. Black will act as a mask, and nothing will be illuminated where the value is black RGB - (0,0,0). It does not need additional masks to hide the lighting

_sss_xtm.Description: This map is for Subsurface Scattering. By default, the diffuse map will also act as a subsurface. But if you want to mix a Subsurface map to a Diffuse, you can also use the (_sss_strength_xtm) map which will act as a mask between the 2 maps

_sss_strength_xtm.Description: This map, which will act as a mask, will decide where the subsurface should be shown and where not.

_transmission_xtm.Description: This map decides where the transmission should be.

_mask_xtm.Standard: Imperfections, Scratch, Smudge ,Fingerprint, Patterns, and much more
_mask_xtm.Description: This map has been given a name for convenience, It can handle, colors, roughness, bump and much more in the FX, it can also turn into a normal map, so it does not need to be accompanied by other maps. It must be in Black and White

_transparent_xtm.Description: This map decides, where the material should be invisible and where not. Black (RGB-0,0,0) is completely invisible, while White (RGB-1,1,1) makes it completely visible. Basically the opposite of the other Black and White maps, where (RGB-1,1,1) is on and (RGB-0,0,0) is off.
